body:
Apparently, others have been similarly bitten by the ambiguity here. See #1265, which was closed as invalid without a clarifying update to the docs. However, [this comment](https://github.com/encode/uvicorn/pull/521#issuecomment-751843304) from @euri10 suggests that uvicorn _**does**_ have the capability to watch all files, and not just those matching `*.py`. @euri10 doesn't expand on that, so I'm not sure if that means watchgod is still required to do that.

If `watchgod` is a requirement of `--reload-include` to exceed some upper bound (beyond "python files", which isn't well-defined), the documentation should make that much clearer, preferably with examples.

Further investigation suggests that @Andrew-Chen-Wang's suggestion isn't valid (unless he was speaking solely of `--reload-include`, in which case the asymmetry is even _**more**_ confusing and certainly not made clear in the existing documentation). The following does not appear to exclude any of the indicated pattens:

``` sh
% uvicorn \
     --reload \
     --reload-exclude '*_flymake.py,flycheck_*.py' \
     --reload-dir /path/to/first_dir \
     --reload-exclude '*_flymake.py,flycheck_*.py' \
     --reload-dir /path/to/second_dir \
     mm.txns.main:app
```

<details>
<summary>Red herring(s) preserved for the curious, but otherwise a distractor to the documentation issues originally presented</summary>

---

Question: Besides backward compatibility, why not lean exclusively on watchgod for all reload behavior and only provide those capabilities if watchgod is installed?

---

The plot thickens‚Ä¶. After installing `uvicorn[standard]`, this works to detect `*.env` changes:

``` python
% uvicorn \
     --reload \
     --reload-exclude '*_flymake.py' \
     --reload-exclude 'flycheck_*.py' \
     --reload-dir /path/to/first_dir \
     --reload-exclude '*_flymake.py' \
     --reload-exclude 'flycheck_*.py' \
     --reload-dir /path/to/second_dir \
     --reload-include '*.env' \
     --reload-dir /path/to/env_dir \
     mm.txns.main:app
```

But it _**stopped**_ working for detecting `*.py` changes in `/path/to/first_dir` and `/path/to/second_dir`. (It still detects changes to `*.py` files in `/path/to/env_dir`, bizarrely.)

``` python
% uvicorn \
     --reload \
     --reload-exclude '*_flymake.py' \
     --reload-exclude 'flycheck_*.py' \
     --reload-dir /path/to/first_dir \
     --reload-exclude '*_flymake.py' \
     --reload-exclude 'flycheck_*.py' \
     --reload-dir /path/to/second_dir \
     --reload-include '*.env' \
     --reload-dir /path/to/env_dir \
     mm.txns.main:app
```

None of what I'm observing makes sense to me, even after reading [`watchgodreload.py`](https://github.com/encode/uvicorn/blob/master/uvicorn/supervisors/watchgodreload.py), so I'm pretty sure there is some attention needed here.

---

_UPDATE: Okay, I _**think**_ I see part of the problem (at least with watchgod). I'm running `uvicorn` in VirtualBox via Vagrant. `/path/to/first_dir` and `/path/to/second_dir` are mounted inside the guest from the host. (However, they are writeable, but that doesn't help things.) uvicorn's non-watchgod implementation doesn't support inclusion as needed (discussed above) and watchgod seems to want to ignore guest-mounted directories entirely. In either case, the behavior and limitations are not well documented. I'm assuming the failure to watch a guest-mounted filesystem is a bug, but the collection of undocumented limitations leaves me to conclude that there's no option that will satisfy my use case. It required about three hours of time to figure this out. I don't think there's any hope anyone could glean any of this from the docs as written. I don't think it's even clear that `--reload-include` requires watchgod._

---

_SECOND UPDATE: I believe I have chased the root cause to why watchgod doesn't notice changes in my setup to this: https://www.virtualbox.org/ticket/10660. So let's treat that as a red herring._

_I think this should be treated like a documentation bug (as was originally intended) in that the existing docs do not adequately describe the observed behaviors and limitations either with and without watchgod._

---

_THIRD UPDATE: Nope. watchgod doesn't use `inotify`. It uses `poll`, which works,_ sometimes, _but I'm not sure when it does and when it doesn't._

_I still think there's a serious problem with the documentation, but I'll ignore the `inotify`/`poll`/`vboxsf` mount weirdness for now._

</detail>

Okay, I might have gotten my understanding of the above wrong as well. After spending more time reading [the code](https://github.com/encode/uvicorn/blob/master/uvicorn/supervisors/statreload.py), it _looks_ like `--reload-include` and `--reload-exclude` have no effect without watchgod. Zero. Zilch. Nada. If that's accurate, without watchgod, `--reload` will recursively look for `*.py` files in all `--reload-dir`s. That's it. I can't see how anyone could reasonably understand that from the current docs, though.

Awesome investigation and apologies for the wrong advice. I believe the reason this was only included for watchgod was because only watchgod had CLI flags for reloading? IIRC, in cookiecutter django, I think I had to manually create a custom watcher to include and exclude what I needed before watchgod implemented the flags. Perhaps take a look at watchgod docs?

I'll try to put together a PR that proposes more helpful/accessible language.

_UPDATE: PR #1331 is up._

issue.body:
The existing docs regarding `--reload` (and adjacent options) were frustratingly vague
and too often led to misunderstandings about specific behaviors. This attempts to
address those documentation deficiencies. Further, this adds a logging warning to
surface to users that `--reload-include` and `--reload-exclude` are ignored unless
Uvicorn is using watchgod to monitor filesystem changes.

Fixes #1326.

# --reload-dir specified, but default dir(cwd) still been watching

Not working as cli help explained:

txt
```
uvicorn --help:
--reload-dir PATH   Set reload directories explicitly, instead
                    of using the current working directory.
```

So, I tried to fix it by counting `self.reload_dirs`, and if it's not provided by arguments, then it will add the default current directory as the watching directory.

Previous discussion: <https://github.com/encode/uvicorn/discussions/1833>

And also: <https://github.com/encode/uvicorn/issues/1326>
